label: Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2)

Hi,

Unfortunately, transferring of EIPs to separate accounts is not supported as of now.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/elastic-ip-addresses-eip.html#using-eip-migration

label: Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2)
description:
Re: Moving elastic ip between accounts
In case someone strays to this page on the same issue; yes, it is possible to move an elastic IP address across accounts. All you have to do is provide AWS with the IP address, the current account number and the target account.  They also need written confirmation from both AWS accounts confirming the transfer requests. This means that the source account has to log a case requesting them to move the IP address to the target account. The target account must also log a separate case requesting them to accept the new IP address which has been moved from the source account.

Unfortunately, there is no self-service available for this type of requirement yet.

label: Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2)
description:
Re: ALB X-Forwarded Headers
Hello 
The X-Forwarded-Proto headers won't be chained by either ALB or the classic load balancer. However for X-Forwarded-For headers, they would get chained by the ALB. 

For example, if a client a.a.a.a is sending a request over HTTP to the ALB which has the following headers
###
X-Forwarded-Proto : https
X-Forwarded-For : a.b.c.d
###

When ALB would forward it to the backend, it would overwrite the X-Forwarded-Proto to HTTP, but it would append the client IP in X-Forwarded-For. Therefore it would look like this 
###
X-Forwarded-Proto : https
X-Forwarded-For : a.a.a.a, a.b.c.d
###

Regards,
Tushar

Our 172.x.x.x private network range has an AWS DNS server I push as primary and then I have a backup, that is never used, as 8.8.8.8. This allows all aws private internal resources to be access over the VPN without any issue from our end users, which primarily use MacOS and Tunnelblick. Everything to support this is on latest release versions and over 50 employees.

 When we started using RedShift, we noticed a weird issue. We reached out to PostgreSQL and even PG Client developers to see if their apps push a hard coded DNS for redshift hostnames, and they do not. This can be an AWS Network or DNS issue or a MacOS libc issue.

label: Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2)
description:
Re: ELB 504 timeout without any attempt to reach web servers
This is ABSOLUTELY a real problem, and not just you. I've had an open support case with them for well over a week now about this. It took them a couple days to actually even accept that there might be an issue with the ELBs.

Just yesterday, they finally came back and admitted that one of our ELB nodes had been experiencing resource exhaustion and that their monitoring hadn't caught it. The ELB team is still investigating for a fix.

One of ways to really call this out to them and make them pay attention is to ask them to look at Cloudwatch graphs of  "Per LB, per AZ Metrics" and compare latencies of the ELB nodes across different availability zones. When you see that most of your nodes are fine, but just one single node suddenly has a huge latency spike that the others didn't experience, it's obvious that that node is having issues and it's not your backend servers.

Stay on them about this. It's the only way they'll address it. They prefer to act like it's the fault of backend servers, or that you are incompetent.

Hello,

I understand your concern but let me convince you otherwise. It has been a practice to save on-premise data to other locations but in the cloud, especially in aws you are in good hands.

You can either do a manual backup via a bash script which will copy the data on your ec2 instance to an s3 and then connect from your on-premise server to download this copy
OR
you can just forget about it. S3 gives you the durability of 99.999999999% saves your data across multiple availability zones and is designed for  99.99% availability which gives you the following:

    Daily: 8.6s
    Weekly: 1m 0.5s
    Monthly: 4m 23.0s
    Yearly: 52m 35.7s

I manage multiple production servers in ec2 and spot instances with very critical data. I don't move them anywhere else knowing that in case something happens I will be able to recover it without any problems.

description:
Re: Not able to connect to EC2 instance through SSH
If you want connect to an EC2 instance's public IP address directly using SSH, make sure you create the EC2 instance with a public IP address in a public subnet. If you're using the non-default VPC, make sure that the subnet is connected to an Internet Gateway in the VPC and the routing table has an entry to route traffic through the Internet Gateway. And make sure it's the correct routing table — I've sometimes accidentally created a new routing table instead of using the default routing table.
